The features of tic

Patrick Schratz, Kirill Müller

Source: vignettes/features.Rmd
features.Rmd

What is the advantage of using tic compared to the default R setup?

  1. Deployment to a Git repository is greatly simplified.

  2. Support for R packages and other kinds of project (bookdown, blogdown, etc.), with predefined templates. Set up your project to deploy rendered versions of your book or blog with a single push.

  3. Workflow specification are specified in a single R script, regardless of the CI system used.
    No need anymore for YAML configuration files that differ across CI services.

Other minor advantages include the use of rcmdcheck::rcmdcheck() for package checking (instead of R CMD check) a and robust caching approach of project dependencies.

Easier deployment

CI services can be used to automatically build and deploy files. This means that these services can push certain files created during the build to repositories (GitHub, GitLab, etc.). Possible use cases are:

  • changed site contents of a pkgdown site
  • updated .Rd files of a package (by calling devtools::document() before)
  • an automatic generated test summary page of a package

If tic should be used for deployment, some preparatory work is required. Luckily, tic takes care of all of this (setting up SSH keys, granting permission for the repo on GitHub and the CI services, creation of a personal Personal Access Token (PAT)). When calling use_ci(), the streamlined preparation process is run. This is only needed once per repository.

For more information on automatic deployment in tic, take a look here.

Support for various R projects

tic was developed with the aim to not only simplify R package development using CI services but also to support other R project types (bookdown, blogdown, drat, website and figshare deployment).

Each of these projects has its own standardized structure. tic detects this structure and adds templates tailored towards this specific project type to the repository when calling use_tic(). See here for a list of supported project types including links to minimal example repositories.

CI-Agnostic workflows

What does “CI-Agnostic” mean and why do we need it?

You may know that Travis CI is not the only company offering (free) CI solutions. Theoretically, R could be run on any CI system. Due to historic reasons, some folks from the R community started on Travis implementing an easy way for R package checking. The build script for R is still community maintained (and always was).

Each CI provider has its own way to specify the setup. Usually it is a YAML file stored at the top-level directory of the repository. This setup file controls what will be done in each run.

To give you an example how different these control files can be, take a look at these two examples from Travis and Appveyor. While Travis is currently the CI service with the most mature R implementation, people also like to test their code on Appveyor which provides support for Windows. Getting everything setup on Appveyor is a bit more complicated than on Travis. Also, Appveyor has its own YAML notation to specify certain actions.

We could list way more differences - but that’s exactly the point when tic comes in!

  • Rather than dealing with all the CI differences, tic enables the specification of the complete workflow in an external R script file tic.R.
  • The commands specified in there will work the same way on every CI service that is supported by tic.
  • Furthermore, you can emulate all the stages and steps locally by calling run_all_stages().
  • You are independent from all the changes that are being made to the R setup for Travis or Appveyor (more info).
  • A tic.R workflow is usually shorter and easier to parse than a .travis.yml or appveyor.yml file.

So instead of learning how to specify specific tasks on different CI platforms, you only apply R commands which work the same on all CI systems.

Less dependency on external CI control commands

Most CI services come with no (native) support for the R programming language. For Travis and Appveyor, the support is provided by the R community. For example, r.rb controls what happens if you set language: r on Travis. All of the commands and arguments specified there can also be set in tic.R using R syntax. So you are no longer dependent on the syntax and restrictions coming from r.rb but able to control the whole CI workflow in a single R file.

Enhanced R package checking: rcmdcheck() > R CMD check

As a R package developer you are most likely used to call devtools::check() or directly R CMD check on your built package. Usually also Travis will run R CMD check to check the R package. tic instead uses rcmdcheck, a wrapper around R CMD build and R CMD check. It was developed by Gabor Csardi. rcmdcheck comes with several enhancements:

  • Coloring of important steps, simplifying the readability of the log
  • Enhanced and extended tracebacks of errors, especially errors in tests
  • The whole check process is returned in a R object, making it easier to inspect errors/warnings

Especially the extended log printing of errors on the CI service is a huge advantage - often enough, CI services cut log output of the console early, omitting important information about the error.

Caching of packages

When using tic, all dependencies (the ones of the package plus the ones of other stages of the CI build) are installed in the "before_install" stage. This has the advantage that all packages get added to the cache (even if they are just needed for deployment), speeding up subsequent builds substantially.

More information about the complete workflow can be found in the Build lifecyle vignette.

Easier troubleshooting

tic comes with the ability to emulate a CI run locally and debug problems in the config file tic.R by calling dsl_load() locally.
